But there is some good news for civilians. It is more likely to die from a crime than from a war. The number of people killed by crime went down. In 2000, 8 people out of 100,000 were killed. News often makes us think the world is becoming more violent. However, there is also cause for optimism. Between the end of World War II and 1990, there were 30 wars that each killed over 100,000 people. Today, civil wars still exist, but countries are generally living together more peacefully than in the past. Yet, terrorism has increased significantly in recent years. Also, since World War II, wars have killed many more ordinary people (civilians) than soldiers. Even for civilians, the statistics are not all negative. Although deaths are nine times more likely to be caused by violent crime than by political conflict, the global murder rate actually fell. It went from 8 out of every 100,000 people in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.

Most people think that developing countries are in a very bad situation. They believe these countries suffer from extreme poverty, are ruled by dictators, and have little hope for real improvement. However, this idea is actually wrong. The truth is that big changes are happening. In the last 20 years, more than 700 million people have earned more money and are no longer poor. Managers give feedback to their workers. They try to make it positive. They often say something good, then something bad, then something good again. This is like a "sandwich." But if managers always do this, workers might think the good words are just to hide the bad words. Then, the good words are not helpful. Good feedback should not just hide bad news. It should help people do good work and want to do more good work.

Managers often try to make their feedback more positive. They do this by giving negative comments between two positive ones. However, if managers always use this method, employees might start to think that the positive feedback is just a way to make the negative feedback seem less harsh. This makes the positive feedback less valuable. Instead, positive feedback should not just be used to soften negative comments. It should be given to strengthen and encourage good work.

I am a member of the 'Campaign to Stop Killer Robots'. We should not think about robots from movies, like the Terminator. Instead, we should think about what is happening now. More people learn English than all other languages together. English is spoken in more countries than any other language. But Chinese has the most native speakers (people who speak it as their first language). A language with many native speakers does not always have many learners. But if a language is spoken in many countries, then many people learn it.

More people are learning English than all other languages combined. English is also spoken in the highest number of countries. However, Chinese has the most native speakers. It seems there is not much connection between how many native speakers a language has and how many people learn it. But there is a stronger link between the number of learners and how many countries speak that language.

First, they say something good. Then, they say what they really want to say. Last, they say something good again.

Your manager tells you she wants to talk about your work on the recent project. You worry all weekend, thinking about what you might have done wrong. On Monday morning, she starts by praising you for the good work you did. You wonder if this is the start of a "feedback sandwich." This is when someone says something nice, then says what they really want to say, and then says something nice again.

Born in the USA is a rock album. The music is fast and makes you want to tap your feet. But the words in the songs are sad and important. They tell stories about the bad parts of the "American dream." Many songs are about normal people who work hard. They feel angry because they don't get rich or famous. Born in the USA is a rock album with fast, catchy music. However, the lyrics of the songs are very emotional and meaningful. Behind the popular rock melodies, the songs tell stories about the difficult side of the "American dream." Many tracks deal with the struggles of ordinary, hard-working people. They feel bitterness and anger because their lives do not bring them wealth or fame. For example, the song "Glory Days" is about people in a small town who look back at their successful youth. Lewis wants to make more parts of the ocean safe. Now, 3 percent of the ocean is safe. He wants 10 percent to be safe. This is to stop damage from people. People catch too many fish, make the water dirty, and throw trash in the ocean. Lewis has seen this damage. He saw coral reefs that were white because the water got warmer. He also saw parts of the Red Sea with no life and lots of plastic. Lewis thinks nature can get better if we give it space. But we must act fast. If we don't take care of our seas, we will have a problem we cannot solve.

Lewis wants to increase the number of marine protected areas in the world from 3 percent to 10 percent. He wants to do this to reverse the damage caused by human activities like overfishing, polluting, and littering. During his expeditions, Lewis has seen this environmental destruction himself. He has swum over coral reefs that were bleached because the water temperature increased. He also observed underwater deserts in the Red Sea, which had no life and were full of plastic. Lewis believes that nature can recover if it is given space to do so. However, the clock is ticking. If we do not start looking after our seas, we may soon have an unsolvable problem.

Terrie Sharp is a best-selling author who is very good at telling stories, as she has won the Olive Crime Writer Award twice. Steven Pinker wrote a book. He says that people are living better lives. We live longer, are healthier, more free, and happier. But Pinker says there is a problem. Some people attack good ideas like using our minds and science. They try to make people angry or not trust others. This can hurt important things like fair government and countries working together.

In his book "Enlightenment Now," Steven Pinker looks at how humans are progressing and finds good news. He says we are living longer, healthier, freer, and happier lives. However, Pinker believes the real problem is that important values like reason and science are being attacked. When people try to make others feel divided, hopeless, or distrustful, it can cause serious harm to important systems like democracy and countries working together.

In old scary movies, people in trouble could not call for help. This made it hard for them to get help. Now, everyone has mobile phones. So, it is easy to call for help. This makes scary movies less believable. To keep movies scary, new films show phones don't work. For example, there is no phone signal. Or the phone battery dies. This always happens when the hero needs help the most.

In older horror films, when the main characters were in a very bad situation, they found it difficult or impossible to call for help or the police. However, mobile phones have made this kind of situation less believable now. To maintain the suspense, a common solution is to show that there is no phone coverage. So, if you are the hero in a horror film, it is almost certain that when you really need to call for help, you will have no signal. Or your phone battery will die exactly when you are making the call. Sometimes, both happen.

In the 1950s, banana growers in Central America had a serious problem. Their most profitable banana, the Gros Michel, also known as Big Mike, was dying. Now, this same problem is happening again to the Cavendish banana, which became popular after Big Mike. The Gros Michel banana was very successful because its fruit was easy to transport, had a thick skin, and tasted sweet. It was the main banana grown on farms in Central America. United Fruit, the biggest company growing and selling bananas then, produced them in a very efficient way. They grew new plants from parts of existing plants instead of using seeds, and planted them very close together in fields.

Spiders have poison (venom). They use it to catch food, not to hurt people. Only 25 kinds of spiders have poison that can hurt people. Spider bites can hurt, but people usually do not die from them. For example, the Sydney funnel-web spider in Australia used to kill people. But since 1981, doctors have medicine (anti-venom) for its bite, so no one has died. Some spiders, like tarantulas, have hair. If they feel scared, they throw their hair. This hair can get into your skin or eyes and make them itchy.

Most spiders have venom, which is a type of poison. They use this venom to catch their food, not to attack people. In fact, only 25 known types of spiders have venom that can actually harm humans. Even though spider bites can be painful, they rarely cause death. For example, the dangerous Sydney funnel-web spider in Australia has not caused any deaths since 1981, when a special medicine (anti-venom) was created. However, you should be careful with hairy spiders like tarantulas. If they feel they are in danger, they protect themselves by shooting out a cloud of irritating hairs. These hairs can then get stuck in the skin or eyes of the person or animal that attacked them.

At the start, this girl is often quiet and not very strong. By the end, she becomes the strongest and smartest person. This last girl almost always wins.

To understand how humans got complex language, we must look at our brains. Our brains are different from animal brains. It is not just about brain size. It is also about what our brains can do and how they changed. We do not have many old things (like tools) that show us how ancient people spoke. But we can see how the mouth, throat, and tongue of early humans grew. About 100,000 years ago, humans could make many different sounds. Before that, scientists can only guess if early humans used simple sounds to talk.

If we want to know how humans learned to use complex language, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals' brains. It is not just about how big our brains are. It is also important to understand what our brains can do and how they changed over time. We have very few physical clues about this; for example, old objects left by our ancestors do not tell us what kind of speech they could make. However, we can see how the mouth, throat, and tongue of early humans developed. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had developed the ability to make complex sounds. Before that time, scientists can only guess if early humans communicated using more basic sounds.

Society tells us that girls should like art, and boys should like maths and science. This is not true. Girls do not see many women who work in science. In cartoons, scientists are often men. People sometimes think scientists are strange, not good with others, or work alone. These ideas are wrong, but TV and movies show them. So, girls might not want to be scientists. They might think science is not a good job for them. If girls saw more women scientists, they would feel better about doing science. They would feel like they fit in.

It is society, not nature, that suggests girls should choose arts and humanities, and boys should choose maths and physics. Also, young people do not see many good examples of women working in science-related jobs. Cartoons and stories often show scientists, inventors, or astronauts as men. There is also a common, but wrong, idea that scientists are strange, not good with people, or that their work is lonely and separate from the rest of the world. These are false ideas shown by the media. Because of this, girls might not feel connected to scientists, and they might see science as a job they don't want to do. If girls saw more positive female role models in science, they would feel more confident and feel more like they belong in these subjects.

The Scallion is a newspaper that is printed weekly and given out for free in university buildings. About 10,000 students read it. Students write and produce the entire newspaper. At Girox Foods, around 12% of employees leave their jobs every year. This might not seem high, but other companies in the same business usually only have 7% of their staff leave. The speaker thought what was said was true. He believes that if people connect too much, they might feel more alone. This is not a big problem for older people. They lived without much technology. They know how to be alone, and they know it's okay. But young people (under 20 years old) are different. They are always talking online. They never have quiet time alone. They might not learn to enjoy being alone. Also, they learn to talk using messages they can change before sending. They don't learn how to talk to people face-to-face, right away.

The speaker agreed with much of what was said. He truly believes there is a danger that the more connected we are, the more isolated we feel. He thinks this is less of a problem for his generation, who lived without technology for a long time. They know how to be alone, and they know it's okay to be alone. However, young people under 20 are a different case. They are so busy communicating that they never experience solitude and might not learn to enjoy their own company. In addition, they learn to have conversations through messages that can be edited and changed. Don't always give good comments and then bad comments. If you always give good and bad comments together, people might not think the good comments are important. They might ignore them. Sometimes, just give good comments. Don't give any bad comments at that time.
